moves.1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 d6 3. Nc3: delayed d4 as I sometimes play Bb5 against an e6 set up.
moves.3... Nf6 4. d4 cxd4 5. Nxd4 a6 6. Bc4 e6: preventing Nxe4 and preparing for Be3 (without the annoying Ng4)
moves.7... Be7 8. Be3: Fairly standard set up against a Sicilian Defense..
moves.9. Bxe6: I was quite happy to give up the Bishop as I get 3 Pawns and leave him behind in development with his king exposed.
moves.10. Nxe6: attacking the Queen and g Pawn
moves.10... Qa5: the only square for his Queen.
moves.13. Nxe7: Wasn't sure if giving up a Knight in such a strong position was best but I felt that the following pin after Bg5 was going to be difficult for him to meet.
moves.13... Kxe7: he has to recapture with his King
moves.14. Bg5: so it seems logical to go for the pin
moves.15. Qd4: increasing the pressure on f6 and also re-pinning the Knight due to the h8 Rook and preparing for Queenside castling.
moves.15... Rg8: I would say that this is a blunder and he obviously missed the combination that follows.....
moves.16. Bxf6: first taking the Knight on f6
moves.17. Qxf6+: the manufactured fork, getting back the sacrificed piece with interest....
moves.19. Nxc7: regaining the Queen but also hitting the Rook on a8.
moves.20. Kf2: Black resigns... as this leaves him 3 Pawns down.
